Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: This movie is so amazing and so powerful. It has one of the best messages a movie can have about hate, and the scene that displays that message the best is without a doubt the scene with Sekani. Hell, when my class watched it, everyone SCREAMED at that part. We usually don't react that much to movies, except at the funny moments. That's how powerful this movie can be. I think everyone should watch it. Another great thing about this movie is the lead. I usually don't care about the main character of movies like this, but I really liked Starr. She never felt like an actor; she felt like a real person that I knew, and that's really good acting right there. And she has the best and most charming and most genuine smile in the world that just makes you want to smile too. The father's pretty good as well. He inspires his kids to do what they think is right and to never be quiet. That's just an awesome parent right there. And the mom's pretty realistic. I mean, she supports Starr for doing the right thing, but she also wants to protect her. The scene where she yells at Starr for going to a protest is so relatable and I think that's exactly what my own mother would say to me if I did what Starr did. Overall this is an awesome movie and everyone should see it.

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: When I went to go see this movie, I went alone because I knew that I would cry....which is exactly happened.  Except I didn’t just cry, I was SOBBING.  This movie really hit me hard because it made me think of the kids at my old high school v. My actual friends.   98% of my classmates were white.  Most of them rich, preppy, from well-to-do families, and simply SHELTERED and IGNORANT.  Almost none of them saw how lucky they were to live in such an affluent area with essentially nothing to truly worry about.  They never saw or were able to comprehend that not everyone has the same privileges and advantages as them; they believed all of the negative stereotypes that the media exaggerates so heavily.  Their ignorance, naivety, and close-mindedness astounded me. To be completely honest, I’m an 18 year old white girl; I know that that shouldn’t matter but unfortunately in this fucked-up world it does.  A lot of people are saying that this movie really hit home to them because they are black, Muslim, etc, and have gone through the same hardships.  I can’t say that I have had the same experiences as them, and I will never EVER say that I truly understand what it’s like because I don’t.  But just because something doesn’t apply to you, doesn’t mean that it’s nonexistent to others

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
It honestly makes me sad that people are still not understanding the message of the movie. The movie or book is not just propaganda, it is set to inform society that our stereotypes can be deadly. Implicit Bias exist for a reason. Prejudice does not always have to be intentional but it does not mean it is less offensive or impactful. When people see a young black man at night with a hood in the hood they automatically characterize him as a criminal. No one has the given right to take someone’s life. If a suspect IS armed it takes one shot to the LEG or LEGS to sedate not 3 or more in the chest to kill. There are so many stories of decades and decades of racial injustice that needs to be heard. The movie is an outlet for those stories to be reached. If you do not understand I suggest research to get educated. 

..And that is my Ted Talk

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
People keeps commenting stuffs about race, propaganda, cops brutality when we completely forgot about the fact that starr and khalil is just a teenager. A teenager who could have a much brighter future, free of violence and injustice in the society. A teenager who could create a change to their community but people waisted their opportunity to do so because their mindset is imprinted by hate. I think the words "THUGLIFE" sets off a really powerful message that is so relevant to what we are dealing right now because we are so caught up with fighting off something thats completely irrelevant to fight for. 

we emphasizes race to the society as if each of them should be mattered no matter what consequences should be taken, but how about us? The youth? The agent of change? Talking about not all white are good and not all black are bad? It doesnt make any sense. At the end of the day, what defines your wellbeing is what you do, not by a statement that you address. Doesn't matter what you look like

But whats concerning in issues like this is how the cycle keeps going and how it affects the younger generations to keep on following the social constructs thats imprinted on hate. Hate creates everything from violence to propaganda or supremacy. Because when we hate, we disagree on things. Seeing people who fight over about conversion propaganda, cop brutality, gun violence just wont solve the fact that if we keep hating on one side, theres always gonna be hostility and no justice.

People keep forgetting that theyre just kids, figuring out life and learning from it. But they had to be exposes in a world full of hate at a young age that it creates fear from both side which can never be compromised if we keep talking about culture and race. Yes you can be differentiated on the color of your skin or the culture you are from, but no matter what makes you, YOU, we can all agree that we are once a teenager trying to figure out life and fighting off of the fear of hate that creates injustice to our life.

Comment: Just finished the book and plan to see this movie soon but I have several serious questions and concerns about not only this story but actual real life society too: Why do some people just not do what law enforcement officers tell them to do? If you actually listened to what you are told to do you could avoid what could escalate into a dangerous situation. What has happened to respect for authority and all human beings in general? Why do people justify crime as the only necessary means to come up with income or respect? Why do people think they have territorial rights to geographical areas that they don’t own? Why don’t people apply discipline and seek to educate themselves to better their lives? Why is it so difficult to speak proper English? Why are children and adults carrying weapons intended to intimidate, rob and kill with? The only thing standing between us and a completely lawless world are the men and women who risk their own lives every day to serve and protect, those individuals have been killed in the line of duty by criminals day in and day out and with the firearms that blight this country being used against them in crimes so is it any wonder innocent people are killed when they don’t comply with straightforward commands? LISTEN and live. Playing the victim because of your race is inexcusable. Find a way to educate yourself, take responsibility for your actions and choices, distance yourself from criminals and crime. When a civilian is killed there are groups of people who use that situation to riot and loot. How is destroying property and stealing from innocent people who had nothing to do with the situation justified? This story does nothing but blame, accuse and fan the flames of HATE.

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: For anyone watching the trailer and thinking that reaching for the brush made no sense let me explain it with a very minor spoiler. He was casually talking to Starr telling her to calm down because he got pulled over for no reason and as he was casually talking he reached for the brush to brush his hair as he waited for the cop to come back to his car. (I dont remember for sure but I think he caught a glance of himself in the sideview mirror and wanted to adjust his hair because he is into his image). He wasn't thinking and did not realize how his actions could be interpreted. But he never pointed the brush at the cop or even lifted the brush up, as soon as he leaned out of the car the cop was already pointing the gun at him. It all happens very fast in the movie and comes out of nowhere. He should have not reached into the car and listend to Starr but the cop was also new and nervous and in the moment of confusion shot out of panic. The trailer slows down the scene to let it register with the audience that he gets shot over nothing. This movie doesn't blame cops, it blames reckless/panicked cops and corrupt cops. Both sides of the argument are explored in this movie. They explore the life of a black american trapped in the ghetto and just trying to get by, the actual criminals and druglords manipulating youngs to do their work so the young can have money to escape the ghetto, and the complicated job of a cop who has to assume the worst in a bad neighboorhood. And ofcourse the cops who are corrupt and immoral and racially profile and the shooter who is just unfit for the job and panics under that sort of circumstance.

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: I love how the movie isn't just one-sided... like "oh cops are terrible they're racist" but the movie also tells all sides of the story and what the people are feeling. People may think blacks sell drugs and stuff because they want to.. but it's not that. It's because they have to resort to that, after going through something hard.. like for example khalil lost his mom and had to take care of his younger brother, so he started selling drugs. But it also tells the police officer's side of the story. Like Starr's uncle said, he wouldn't shoot if it was a white man in a suit. He also tells Starr what it's like in the situation. Things go through their mind like "oh, is the girl okay, did she just get raped, is he not following orders because he's hiding something, is he going to reach for a weapon?" One thing I also learned though.. is that if a white man covered in tattoos, piercings, wearing pants that sag and a tanktop, and he was disobeying orders... There's a 50% chance the cop would shoot and not say "put your hands up" compared to if the guy was wearing a suit, well dressed, and had a nice car. This movie gives a good message overall, and explains what goes through somebody's mind when they see this happen. I already saw the movie, but I'd honestly go see the movie 10 more times.

Comment: If an armed cop instructs you to put your hands up where they can see them, just do as you are told. If you believe you are being harassed by the cops, then make sure you obey every instruction you are being given in order not to get shot. It is more astute to live to protest about it later than to get shot and have others protest about it later. Refusing to obey an instruction and then reaching inside the car when you've just been told to put your hands up isn't protesting. It's just asking to get shot. Cops get shot at all the time, which is why they get really nervous when someone is belligerently refusing to obey their instructions. Cops don't have x-ray eyes. Then can't see whether you are reaching for a gun or another weapon to harm them. They will pre-emptively shoot you. I don't know why this concept is so difficult for humans to grasp.

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: Sometimes the problem is not even with being racist or profiling but rather the lack of proper training for our police officers. A great example that we could learn from is the UK. They use a firearm as a last resort. Sadly, here in the U.S. it is kind of hard to do so because people can be unpredictable. It is still not an excuse to use your last resort weapon as your, "shoot first ask questions later". It's sad seeing our officers shoot people due to misunderstandings. I do agree with others about just following what the officers says. EVEN if you did not do anything wrong. If you get pulled over, just proceed to identify yourself, simple as that. Yes, you DO NOT have to, but you learn in the movie by not obeying a simple task, you put the officer into thinking that there may be something wrong. They need to be cautious because their lives are also in danger, therefore do not give an officer the wrong idea by not obeying. This is where maybe, a better training could come in handy if maybe the officer seems aggressive. When I got pulled over for speeding, there were no complications what so ever. I did as he told me and continued, anyway, great movie nonetheless!!

Comment:
So many triggered liberals (who we all know are stupid) and triggered anti-SJWs (who call themselves conservative but have absolutely no idea about what real conservatism is) in these comments. The media’s false coverage leads to the mutual mistrust between minorities and cops that allow these horrible things to happen. The cop expects resistance, the victim expects brutality, the victim doesnt realize the threat because he falsely believes the brutality is just a stereotype. He doesn’t listen, and is depiction of a threat will force the violence to happen. 

There are some really fucked up cops out there.

And there are some really fucked up thugs out there who people say are the victims.

The Black Community has issues that nobody can deny, regardless of their political opinion. Liberals say that white people are the only reason it happens, and the U.S government is a regime that is imposing a reign of terror. Conservatives say the issues are black people’s fault because it is proven that more black people are killed by other black people, and the really ignorant ones somehow conclude that they don’t deserve help because of that. Both of those statements are stupid. I’m not gonna sit here and deny facts. Helping people by giving a positive representation of both sides is the perfect way to solve this. The cops and the “victims” will come closer to understanding one another, and unnecessary violence can be avoided. Tupac almost did it, but since then we have taken a few steps back. Nobody is able to do that though. The media really fucks everything.

I support Trump and 100% love conservatism. Conservatism believes in equality of opportunity, Liberalism believes in equality of outcome. Equality of opportunity puts power in people to better improve their own lives for themselves and their children. Equality of outcome puts power in the government to allow for them to intervene in people’s lives so that the people and their children benefit. These cop-hating liberals preach “power in the people” but if you truly believe in that then you believe in equality of opportunity. 

Liberals are ignorant. But many Conservatives are too. Neither liberals nor ignorant conservatives are open-minded enough to see the better things for this.

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: All in all - it makes me SICK we as American's have such a divide this day and age of 2018. we came so far, then we set ourselves back - until we admit that "White's" do have privileges and those of other culture or race do not, it will sadly continue, if you are white shaking your head, go be on the flipside and see for yourself. I have not read the book yet, but watching this trailer made my heart sink because a life was lost period. Why because of his color, sadly because of his color.  White or Black, if it would have had the same outcome, who knows, but we do know here, it was because he was black.  All I know is it happens like this a lot in our world and it shouldn't.  What I have seen here was slow movements by him, and his body language said nothing of the sort of being defiant or defensive or to be feared,  he was leisurely hanging back talking to his girl. His movements were slow and he wasn't even turned to the officer when he pulled the hairbrush up by his head, granted  I want to see the whole movie, but that is what I seen in this trailer.  I heard no warning from the officer to stop, drop it, turn around with your hands in the air, NO WARNING - nothing of the sort just a shot, he acted out of fear, but really fear of what?  I would hope an pray the good officers of this world in certain situations, will use their voice first then act on what they see because they are trained correctly, not just an assumption without assessment and yes they have to think fast and on the defense.  Usually, as an officer I would also think, you would have a heightened sense of "danger" or "fear" from the citizens you pull over, here I see nothing but compliance and just a couple of teens out on a date, nothing to be feared of, not even the mood in the voices or their body language would you assume fear, so why would you assume he is a danger. Obviously, this officer has no sense or 6th sense of being for his job, to access the situation, he just acted without thinking, but really he couldn't have felt fear for his life from them.  And a taser would have sufficed, to deploy any other danger of moving in a defensive manner.  We have lost the main groundings of life, the compassion for other humans, love, respect. I don't care who you are, this happens and it needs to stop, but not by violence, by teaching that every life matters in this world, no matter who you are, because we only get one!!!

The fact that he shot the kid before asking what was in his hands was a huge violation 3. The cop jumped to conclusions. Now all of you who keep defending the cop, no matter the race of you, are wrong. That man should be fired and arrested. We live in a world or racism, and everyone turns a blind eye. This book and movie are very POWERFUL. This may not be the first movie to show it, but we need more voices, and more books and movies about this. This isn't something that there is enough of. Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
Honestly, it is probably more of a class issue than a race issue. However, grouping up by class especially in America is harder when grouping people by race is so easy especially when the usual identifiers of class; being the way in which you speak, how you carry yourself (posture and gate), and how you treat your possessions (rubbish in the car vs well maintained (not necessarily the value of the vehicle)), are often especially in the media used to identify the different racial cultures in the states.

Someone who exudes the appearance of class is usually attributed with adjectives like 'respectable', 'responsible', and 'rational'. Such a person has things they don't want to lose, values themselves and others and finally doesn't act on impulse. A policeman addressing an individual like this will be less wary that they will draw a pistol, try and escape or exhibit reckless behavior.

On the other hand, someone who lacks this appearance may have an untidy car, unkempt appearance, communicate in slang/pigeon or as though they missed more than a few days of school, have a peculiar/erratic gate/movement or poor posture will cumulatively add up to exude the appearance of low class. Which invokes the words 'unrespectable', 'unresponsible', and 'irrational'. It would be to these people that a question like "Is that your kid in the car?" is an actual question rather than par for the course, and of whom the policeman will be far more wary of drawing a pistol or weapon on him.

Unfortunately, it seems as though most media (even this film does it), actively portrays black communities as being not well off and also exhibiting some elements of 'low class' behavior. It seems as though unlike some other countries classful behavior has become racial signaling in most black communities where proper vernacular is deemed as being 'white' and something to avoid reinforcing the likelihood that people remain socially immobile and in these sectioned communities.

Even in the most ethnically homogenous societies, low-class people can still be picked up on based on the attributes outlined, sometimes with their very first utterance. The exception is that there is no racial sections of society which feel as though being low class is who they are, while there are people still in such countries content with being low class there is no admiration for such class and many openly strive to raise their class in the hopes that they will obtain social positions matching the class they emulate. Even in such homogenous societies, the perceived lower class are roughed up more by police with more injuries and overnight prison stays.

Most of what I refer to are generalizations that people/communities exhibit/perform and tensions caused. There very well may be exceptions, but the rules explain the data and human behavior.

tl:dr - Wealthy or upper-class black people in America are so in spite of rather than because of the low-class culture oft-identified with by the black communities (generalization). Law enforcement is more wary of low-class people who tend to be viewed by all as having less to lose financially and socially while also tending to be more irrational or violence-prone (generalization).

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: I understand he was shot for not following the officers instructions, and because he was reaching for something inside the car, yes, he had it coming. However the officer could've gone for the thigh, shoulder, elbow, hand, something non-lethal that would incapacitate him. Also the wiki says in the movie the boy was shot three times, that's 2 shots overkill. But 1st: What were they even pulled over for? At 1:05 and 1:08 there were no stop signs, no traffic lights to run, and it didn't seem like they were speeding, so what were they pulled over for? 2nd: Couldn't he have just tased him? Google says police tasers can fire from up to 30 feet, I'm sure he was in range. I agree, the riots and molotovs and such are way overboard and unnecessary, if you're going to protest, do it peacefully like The Civil Rights movement, but in truth they should take the officer to court. With Starr sitting in the passenger seat, a witness to exactly what happened, they might be able to get him punished and hopefully even fired for what he's done. "He was caught in the heat of the moment" someone will probably say, well if you can't think quickly enough to get optimal results out of a situation, perhaps you shouldn't be a police officer, or at least be re-assigned to desk duty. To conclude, there were bad moves on both sides.

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
This trailer worries me - the book has so much inner dialogue and frustration and understanding that a movie I feel can't accurately portray without changing bits and pieces. Obviously, a movie is generally not identical to the book inspiration, but changing too much can be dangerous for the message. 
Something that bugged me was Khalil's representation in the situation with the cops in the scene where he gets shot. In the book, Khalil is VERY concerned for Starr's safety so he leans ever so slightly into the car to ask her if she's okay. The cop sees the hairbrush, assumes Khalil is threatening to shoot him and then acts. In the trailer, Khalil dramatically whips out a hairbrush while talking to Starr with a big goofy grin on his face...

Comment: Race baiting film. I guess it's okay to publish something in today's media that is obviously suppose to empower certain people to stand up to a race that has no ties to the atrocities our ancestors committed. We were raised on the same curriculum as you. In the same time period. We think alike and want equality. But now standing up to police and being rebellious is in the now. I've seen officers defend themselves countless times. I've also seen officers lose their lives to people simply trying to get out of an expired license. If you think for a second that any officer, seeing the things they've seen is going to let some lowlife be the reason they don't get to see their wife and kids again. You have another thing coming. No amount of protesting, marching, or shooting police officers on their lunch break will change any of that. They shoot whites more frequently than blacks. Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
So dumb kid acts stupid by grabbing a brush while pulled over by cops at nighttime, cops mistake brush with gun (and with it being nighttime, they wouldn’t be able to see it clearly) and shoot him out of fear (keep in mind they don’t care if it’s a kid, they’re worried about themselves like any cop would, and the moment that a cop would second-guess if that gun is really a gun is the time that they will get shot instead), and now the community makes the kid a martyr thinking it’s some racism issue that a white cop shot a black kid when it’s just the kid acting stupid. Oh boy. 

I can understand that the movie is trying to deliver a message, but maybe if the kid was shot doing nothing, or if instead he ducks his head into the car to check on the Starr girl see if she’s alright and gets shot by the cop who cries that he thought he was reaching for a gun, that would be more believable and make more sense, especially when the kid wouldn’t look stupid doing it either. If you want to make a message ring out, don’t cancel it out like this with the kid acting stupid. Now, I haven’t read the book, but I hope the kid that gets shot wasn’t dumb in it too.

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
Will be interesting to see what *yet another film* on the Black/white, black/cop, and poor/rich divides in our society does. Being that our society is already severed on multiple faults, I'm not expecting much.

From a narrative standpoint, the movie seems to take offence that the shooting of this kid would be in any way justified; However, while it is a tragic event, it wasn't random violence, and its not just the boys friends, family, and neighborhood that are affected. The cop will have to live with the fact he shot an unarmed man, and the black community will never let him move past it. The entire police-force of that city and, with the advent of social media, most of the nation, will have to deal with the fallout of an outraged congregation.

Multiple episodes in the Cop drama, Blue Bloods,  deal with this facet- Its set in a modern day progressive New-York, and deals with the White, Irish-Catholic family that is the Reagan clan. It does a very good job of showing that even those "in power" are not always the most powerful people in a situation- I'd highly recommend watching it as well as this movie, so that you get to see the issue from both sides- One look from the point of view of a smart, black teenager from the ghetto, and that of her family, the other from a family of honorable cops (most notably Danny and Jamie, one a seasoned, hard-ball detective who steps on the line, the other a lawyer turned cop, your classic boy-scout who follows the rules as far as they're written). 

It'll also be interesting to see how many people care that the shooting of this 17 year-old kid, while tragic, is more understandable if viewed from another perspective beyond the one shown in the trailer and, as I can reasonably assume, the movie.

While I will agree that the use of force is something to be avoided *if possible*, the definition of just how possible it is has to stop at some point. A cops first job is to take criminals, whoever they may be, off the street, and the second job entailed in that is to keep ordinary, law abiding people safe. In this particular case, the officer doesn't know what the man he just pulled over has, and it could be something deadly to him or to any nearby citizens- for sake of example, a gun. 

All that taken into consideration, you are now in the following scenario:
A man you just pulled over is reaching inside his car, to grab some object. It is dark, and you don't know the man, so would have no idea as to whether he is violent or not but for the at most couple of minutes you've known him since pulling him over. As he pulls his hand back, you can see an object in his hand- You don't know what the object is- Maybe its a gun, maybe its a hair-brush. Pair that with the fact the individual in question has not only disobeyed your commands, but is currently in a decently high-stress situation- Being pulled over (for whatever reason). Hes roughly 20 feet from you- A fair distance to have to close with a knife, but possible given the circumstances, and more than within easy range of a handgun- You aren't a far off observer, you are right there, in the thick of it. Your life, the life of his passenger, his life, and anyone nearby hangs in the balance of whether or not you act on what this man pulled out of his car.

What do you do?

Comment: Man I gotta say this movie just rubs me the wrong way. I feel like this movie is trying to send out a message that is just completely false. I’ve always had a hard time understanding why white people get the blame. The big issue here is the media. Media is pushing out these stories that you see on the news primarily black shootings, which makes the whole population believe that black shootings are at an all time high and all of them are unjustified. I believe in facts and evidence. Most of the people on the news that have been shot and killed by police have a simple headline such as “man killed for selling CD’s”. Obviously that wasn’t the case, the man wasn’t shot just for selling CD’s. And most of the other “unjustified shootings” that you see on the news are just fabricated. Is it very unfortunate that people are dying when probably it could’ve been preventable? Yeah it’s pretty sad. But you also have to think, are you safe right now because they are out there doing they’re job? Yes (if not maybe move to a different location). Just please try to put yourself into a cops shoes and if you see someone reaching for something, what would you do? I’m not on here to argue or anything I’m just making a statement of which I believe. You can say what you want but please try to keep it civilized. Also if you want to check out a video by Steven Crowder , it’s called “BLACK LIVES MATTER DEBUNKED” it really just puts a lot of things into perspective and separates the truth from the lies. Have a good one and please start a conversation with me, I don’t mind

Comment:
Reading all those comments where people are saying that "we are once again victimizing" black people. (Said a black person, apparently) Or saying that the cop was right, that Khalil shouldn't have made a move... WORST, that the cop was scared and its NORMAL. 
No. It's not normal that he'll be scared at the point of killing a kid with 3 shots. 3 shots. Was it the only way he could of 'defend' himself?
If he was that scared of "living a dangerous life" always in the center of crime he should have chosen to work in a kindergarten. 

Khalil got shot because of the preconcieved ideas of the cop. Because if he was black, he was 'probably' a gangster. He was 'probably' a dealer. He was 'probably' armed... even when he didn't found any guns on him.
So it didn't matter. His life didn't matter. 
But the cop didn't know anything about him. He didn't even knew is name. He just presumed, he just took those assumptions to excuse the murder he later commited. 
But you know what? Black lives matter. Khalil life mattered.

Comment: Okay so I can tell from the comments not a whole lot of people have really read this book. In this book it is from only Starr's point of view. How she viewed the situation,not the officers. In this situation the author made one of the police officer committing police brutality not the other way around,keep in mind this is a story so Angie the author made it from one point of view and a story that was on *Police Brutality* throughout the book the police officer is very nasty and just disrespectful - trying not to give spoilers but there was something huge that wasn't in the trailer that happens in the book,not sure if it's involved in the movie but reading the book it makes a whole lot more sense as to why the police officer wasn't a 'good guy'.  So really one thing you need to keep in mind is that this is purely a story on police brutality,there's many cases where it isn't police brutality but in this story it was. Don't get mad about the title too,it was literally,not even joking, inspired by Tupacs tattoo and quote.

Comment: Now I know I am going to get some shade for my comment, but here it goes....Black people!! We have gone through many hurdles in our society when it comes to race, but there is now colorism that is dividing us.  I have never heard white people say "why did they not cast an irish person for the role? or an Asian person commenting that they should have cast a Japanese person instead of Chinese.  We are hurting each other more than any other race that is causing us harm when we chose a person's "shade" to attack.  Yes people see those with dark skin as less beautiful, but really beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.  What people are actually fighting is lack of self confidence in their skin and covetousness!!.  So now people who are light skin have to fight both darker skin people and white people?  Why are black people afflicting their own?  Again how can a nation rise if divided? Hollywood has always gone to current actors at the time to bring in ratings and it is very rare that they will gamble with unknowns. Amandla is one of those current actresses.  Black people wish her well and learn to build each other up, not bring each other down!!

Comment:
That one line is how every Man need to learn to comport himself.

Girl: "I've got a boyfriend."

Boy: "We've been together our whole lives...we got time."

That's not to say that you should drop all options and wait for your ideal girl...NO, it's simply to say that you should never sweat any single girl....be patient in the reality that things CAN change but may not necessarily to the direction of your greatest hopes and ENJOY the person for who they are as much as they can give you in that moment. If you want more and you share that with them and they relent and you chose to stay....THAT'S ON YOU. If they go and get married with "boyfriend" THAT'S ON YOU for not living your life while you were building friendship with them. This may be hard for some of you to logically parse but you are Human before you are a Man.

Comment:
I can already tell this is doing a disservice to not only the book but to the topics of police brutality and black lives matter. I'm in support of the movement and the book was also phenomenal but with even "little" details changed it changed the whole story.  The problem with Khalil (the friend hero was killed) being killed was that he didn't reach into the car, he got unlawfully pulled over, was pulled out of his car for asking why he was pulled over, and was shot not once or twice but three times while he was unarmed and had nothing remotely dangerous or unlawful in his car.  Then the cop proceeded to get off the hook with no charges and not even suspension. The book doesn't portray all cops as being bad in fact the opposite it shows that most cops are good but there are a selected few that are racist and/or abuse their power. 
They changed Khalil into reaching into his car for a dark colored brush when he was told to stay still which is reason to shoot in a cops mind. The whole anger and rioting is that Khalil was unarmed and listened and followed instructions of the cop and was still shot 3x. It shoes the systematic oppression of black people and how all evidence can point to unlawful and unjust and they still get off the hook cuz theyre white.

Comment:
My biggest problem with this movie is the fact that Amandla Stenberg had been cast as Starr. It doesn't matter what Angie said, the way she chose to portray Starr on cover of her book is what was expected and that was a dark-skinned black girl. Not only is Amandla light skinned, she's mixed race. The book says that Starr is a cross between her parents and in this movie she's lighter that BOTH OF THEM. After all of Amandla talk about being pro black and quote unquote "dropping out" of Black Panther to let darker skinned girls "have a chance", this is something else she also should have deemed important for a darker girl to have. I'm not only upset with her for snatching the role, but also with the casting directors for putting her in it. For some reason, Hollyweird seems to have the misconception that movies featuring dark skinned people won't sell as much but Black Panther was full dark skins and culture and completely smashed the box office. Coincidence? I think not. 
I have a problem with accepting biracial people as black because when we do, they become the face of our community and that becomes a problem. They are then deemed the "acceptable" black people and the rest of us are then misrepresented. Don't even tell me that Amandla is black enough because she isn't, she's really not. This just throws Starr's entire story out the window because it's supposed the represent the darker skinned community and the prejudice against us but at the end of the day, I guess Amandla cares more about
 making money than the message. Not to mention that her acting isn't that great yet everyone continues to hype her up.

Comment: I haven't read the book, but from what I can tell by the trailer, it looks like a movie based on false assumptions and illogical thought process. The problem is, the boy was pulled over by the cop, probably for a sobriety test or something of the sort, because if he was in high school and driving a car, there typically is a curfew on the license, and given they were at a party, chances are it was past curfew. Also the boy was shot because he was pulling a nondescript item from his vehicle when he as asked to get out of his car, probably for a routine sobriety test because he was out so late. Had he not been so ignorant, he probably would have gone through the sobriety test easily and been on his way. The cop didn't shoot him because he was racist.

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
This story, this book, and this movie were not made to depict the police in a negative way it was made to bring attention to the fact that black people everywhere are subjected to racial profiling even if it’s not necessarily intentional. The people saying that stories like this only cause a divide and make the problem worse, it only does so when people automatically assume the worst, when people don’t look at the whole picture. 

Stories like this do need to be out there. Not for the sake of demonizing the police, making martyrs out of people, and creating a divide; but for the sake of starting and creating a conversation. If you never speak about the problem it starts to become the normal, and we can’t let taking the lives of the innocent because of situations like the one in the book become normal. Bringing attention the problem allows for a window of opportunity to make a change. 

“What’s the point of having a voice if you’re gonna be silent in the moments you shouldn’t be?”

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
The real story, the one in the book, never had Khalil, the boy who was shot,  grab the hairbrush. The only thing he did was check on Starr to asks if she was okay. I have no idea why the movie changed it because people who haven’t read the book will now interpret it wrong and may say the shooting was justified but that isn’t what actually happened.

If you read the book you can clearly see that the police officer was being excessive and more aggressive than was necessary. The cop was not doing his job right. The reason everyone was protesting and rioting was because this was a 16 year old black kid living in a neighborhood that was known for drugs, violence, etc, and that was ultimately the reason he was shot, due to racial profiling the cop just assumed they were bad kids and they were up to no good. And let’s be honest if this were a white person or a person with light skin this would not have been the result, there are steps that need to be taken and there’s proper protocol for everything. Because he was a black man he was automatically suspected. 

And to the people who may say that the cop was scared for his life, that’s not a reason to take the life of a kid, of a living breathing person, because of an error in judgment. Cops are properly trained for those types of situations, and what the cop did in this story was clearly wrong and misguided.

So no, no it was not his fault that he got shot, he didn’t point the gun at himself.

Comment: Sometimes, you read a book and it fills you with this weird evangelical zeal, and you become convinced that the shattered world will never be put back together unless and until all living humans read the book. Angie Thomas is an amazing author, and I hope the whole world will read this book.

Comment: This movie is an unbelievable affront to Law Enforcement Officers everywhere. Though I am retired, we dedicated Our Lives to fighting criminals and protecting the innocent. This movie makes us look like bastards and murderers. It is wrong. It is especially wrong to sensationalize racism, to say it is more than it is, and to say that all police officers are wrong and horrible. There is a United States Supreme Court case, Tennessee versus Gardner, that specifically authorized is officers to utilize lethal Force when it is objectively reasonable. Want to subject is given clear and distinct verbal commands to remain where he is. Once stepped out of the vehicle, and then he goes back to the vehicle, and is told to stop, we believe it is to retrieve a weapon to kill us. That is a reasonable assumption, because many officers have died for exactly that reason. The subject then pulls out an object with his hand. He is again told to stop and refuses. The officer fires. That is the way it is. The subject would be alive if he had obeyed officers commands. This movie is unbelievable and that it ignores all of this. I call on police officers firefighters Medics security guards and all good and decent people to boycott any theater that attempts to play this. Because they are attempting only to destroy law enforcement and Advocate our destruction.

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: When I first saw this trailer I was a bit mad that the plot revolved around a teen who was shot after being told by the police to keep his hands on the car. I don't care if you're black, hispanic, white, asian or whatever. If a cop directs you to keep your hands on the car, you do it. It's for the cop's safety. The reason is because some people (not him) go to reach for weapons. The cop doesn't have time to think it over because IF that is a weapon he may be too late. Having said that, I'm glad that people in the comments have stated that in the book he didn't reach. That is a much better conclusion and conveys the point they're trying to make. I wish they'd stuck with the book version. The movie looks good, can't wait to see it!

Comment:
I came to the comments expecting the people who were pissed off/didn't like the trailer would be those that chant  "blue lives matter" everywhere. Instead, it's filled to brim with black people saying that she's not black enough. Come on. There's already people that are going to hate it because of they don't want this storyline to be depicted, don't do the same here. 

The author wrote the book, and the author had a heavy hand in choosing the cast (I came to an event she was speaking and she loves Amandla. And saying we see her everywhere, are you kidding? There's people like Angelina Jolie or Scarlett Johanson, all one shade of white who are literally in every single movie. Let Amandla get big. Let her pull other small actors with her. Support her and the movie (if you enjoyed the book). I have a feeling that the movie might be better (not saying the book wasn't good, but I was looking more of a deeper look into race. I don't know if the movie will give that, but the trailer looks promising).

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: I cannot express in words how much this story touched me and opened my eyes to what is actually going on. Growing up, I did see stories like this on the news by never actually gave them the importance I should have given, because as a white child, it didn’t really affect me. After reading this book, I finally understood everything that has been going on, and now that it has become a movie adaptation, I REALLY hope it reaches as many people as possible, mainly the younger generations. Racism and white privilege is still a thing! And just because it never happened to you or someone you know, doesn’t mean that you should turn your back on it.

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: As good as this movie looks something just doesn’t sit right with me. I just don’t kinda like how this trailer portrays public high schools in lower income neighborhoods. Now Starr’s experiences were based off Angie Thomas’(the author) and how she had to live a double life basically. I get that. But I feel as if the movie kinda overgeneralizes about how students at private and public schools function. I’ve known girls who have gotten addicted to meth and one who got a pregnant yet their parents payed 13 grand a year for their education. I know the tuition price because I was gonna attend there as well but stuff fell short. All the while I’ve known dedicated kids who attend public schools,dedicate their life to their education etc etc. But because they go to a C minus Niche rated school they’re not taken seriously.Where does this narrative leave those dedicated students who DO go to schools in lower income neighborhoods. I hope I’m wrong. I really do. This is just a trailer so I still have high hopes. Just that wording about the school gave me a weird feeling. But I’m probably just reading in too deep into it and it’s gonna be a great movie. In elementary I  went to private but hung around neighborhoods on the lower economic scale. Where food and necessities are just more affordable. Most of my classmates had dads who golfed on the weekend while My dad had to work. So dear god I pray this movie executes it’s message well.

Comment: My only question is, if this film was the other way around would everyone be mad instead? I know this film is based off the book and I understand the context of the shooting. However, what if it followed a white cop and he saw someone reaching in their vehicle and he didn't act and was shot. Then the story moved to a black cop who didn't shoot a suspicious white man and was shot by him, then a Hispanic cop walking down the street and getting blown away. Every race fights eachother and these films fuel those fights. I've never been racist towards any race, it's unfair to assume, but I've been assumed to have privileges, but the truth is just last week I got pulled over and he told me to put my hands on the dash, why? To be safe. Everyone wants to be safe.

Comment: and please realise that the brush Khalil is holding/using is not the point. it may look funny (or as I've also read in other comments, 'stupid' or 'foolish') to some people, as he seems to be goofing around or trying to lighten the mood, but the message is that sometimes the trigger gets pulled a second too soon for things as 'funny' as a hair brush. in situations as tense as 2 black people being pulled over *without a clear reason*, even a *hair brush* can be seen as gun or something else (I'm not judging the act of Khalil taking the hair brush, I simply want to make it clear that it's not intended as a joke. remember how a great number of real life cop shootings happened because it *looked like* the person drew some kind of weapon. so my point: look past the 'funny hair brush act' and see the real message before making a joke about things) This scene is not funny, it's more pugnant because it makes an important point, not a pun

Comment:
"I got a boyfriend."
"Yeah, I heard. It's all good."
"Really?"
"Been together all our lives, Starr. *We got time.* "
When you think about this scene after what happens, it makes you want to cry even harder. Innocent lives are lost...Their dreams and hopes taken away due to irrational fear and hate. 

It saddens me how realistic this scenario is. And yet nothing changes. Same events repeat, just a different name. We're becoming used to news like this...and that's when you know that humanity has come to the lowest point possible. When will things like these become a part of history textbooks that children read and find incomprehensible that it even happened? I don't want this to be our present.

Comment: No hate to Amandla (or Zendaya she's my idol), I'm super hype to see this movie, but It's always Zendaya or Amandla that's cast as black women in movies. Even when the character is specified as medium brown/cocoa color they still choose one of Hollywood's "typical" black girls. As a dark skin teen who was super psyched for a dark skin or medium skin girl to play the role, I was a little disappointed, but not surprised, by their choice for the lead role. Amandla's gonna be amazing though, no hate towards her at all, I'm still super psyched to see it. I just wish they would venture out and discover all the amazing dark skinned actresses that could do this role just as well and fit the description in the book. It's more than just skin tone, it shows the implicit effect of colorism in society and the movie industry.

Comment: I understand why people feel the need to think this "needs" to come out, but its honestly creating more of a divide than it is helping thing. I honestly find this concept to be a little racist. "only white people are rich, and only black people can be poor" and this "all cops are evil and hates all black people" thought that is being put through peoples minds these days is dangerous and only leads to more violence and hate. Is it bad when cops fire prematurely? Absolutely, however it doesn't happen all the time, and a lot of situations that people point to as proof that it does happen aren't actually situations where the cops fired prematurely. I seem to recall a year or so ago when a lot of stories about trigger happy white cops were shooting black people were heavy and not even a week before a white kid was shot and it never made it to the headlines. Everything about the politics of this is messed up.

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
This is gonna be the first time I've read a book way before there was mention of a film, and now I understand the partial frustrations that may arise when your favorite book is being adapted into a film 🙃

In the book, Khalil doesn't pick up his hairbrush while instructed to stand beside the car. He only peeps in through the window to ask if Starr is okay. By making him take out a *hairbrush* , despite being pulled over and instructed to stand beside the car, the movie makes him look more careless/disobedient than he was--making it easier to defend the cop in this situation.

But to clarify/discuss a little about what happened in the book, while Khalil did initially respond with annoyance toward the cop, we *know* he didn't do anything wrong to begin with. Granted Khalil could have sounded more respectful/polite as he asked why he was pulled over, but he is human. And when one's pulled over for presumably no reason, besides perhaps racial profiling, we can see why one would be a bit annoyed. The cop's human too, so of course this rubs him the wrong way. But, going off how the event played out in the book, to make the assumption Khalil was reaching for a gun because he ducked his head in a window while the cop was at his car? Khalil should have known better than to move (even if his intention was just to check on his friend), but come on. That was the reason to shoot? *Several* times? The cop's retelling of the events with false information even suggests that the cop realizes how bad the telling of the true events would make him look. So in this specific instance, one should most certainly side with the victims. 

Anyways, back to the original point of this comment, the use of the hairbrush in that movie scene is bothersome for me as one who read the book, but I have to remind myself that this is an adaptation of the book--not a carbon copy. I'm still excited to see how well they did depicting the story along with its overall message! 🤙🏾

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: I heard about this movie and I just had to read the book first. I'm confused as to why people are complaining about Amandla as Starr, in the book, Starr is described as 'caramel-skinned' (but she hates being called that) and her mum is 'high yella' while her dad is dark-skinned. Also, did I mention that the mother's brother's name is Carlos? Sure, a non-hispanic person may have a Hispanic name, but that and the 'high yella' painted to me a picture of some sort of admixture, so Amandla does fit the profile, by skin colour and by admixture. The dark-skinned girl on the cover is what threw people off, and I thought Starr was dark-skinned too from the cover but she's really not. Apparently, the cover has nothing to do with Starr's physicality but with #BLM. Yes, colorism is absolutely a thing and we have to work towards fixing that but in this case, it appears that the casting of Starr was done by the book. Turns out, even the writer recommended that Amandla be Starr.

Comment:
Things not so appealing about the movie version:

1. Starr’s skin color (but it doesnt bother that much anymore)
2. Seven doesnt have dreads
3. The whole ‘Hair Brush in the car’ situation is different here... 
4. She isn’t supposed to say anything to officer 1-15, she’s supposed to just say «no» and look mortified. That was the best part of the book. The fact that she was speechless. Why did they make her talk

Good things about the book:

1: UNCLE CARLOS IS EXACTLY LIKE I IMAGINED
2: KJ looks so much better with this hair color
3: the setting is perfect
4: Regina hall is perfect as Starr’s mom
5: Hayley looks like the biatch she is supposed to be
6: Ms. Ofrah actually looks like an activist :))

Well anyway, it seems good and i can’t wait. I know not everything is gonna be the same as in the book but i hope they don’t change a lot :)

Title: The Hate U Give | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: As a African American 13 year old female looking at this made me realize the world is filled with prejudice and power. It hurts to see our black brothers being the ones to be hurt by the prejudice and stereotypes from our white officers who say there are here to "protect the community" protect the community officers does not require you killing black people. What's more worse is to see so many of these officers tell young black kids that they are the "good" guys and they would help "save" You. U know what hurts is seeing black kids tell their parents that they want to be a police officer some day. Why does this feeling of guilt come to us when black children are blind sided by the effects of their white heroes who only hurt them(blacks) the most. Did our black fellow members not get their voices heard when they said "BLACK LIVES MATTER" I feel depressed every time I turn on the news to only hear a black teen or a black man get killed by an officer and to see the officer make excuses or say "Oops that was the wrong one" the President should be helping us blacks deserve justice for our fellow black brothers and sisters who were gunned down because of a gun being pointed to them. I know this is to much of me writing but I wish us blacks deserve the justice we need.

Start doing something about it instead of antagonize & talking. This movie doesn’t help the cause it only s brain washes today generation and tomorrows.  Being a cop isn’t easy. Making 30,000 to 50,000 a year, 15 hours shifts with a wife & kids at home to balance is hard. One bad cop doesn’t speak for the rest. There cops that just want to do it for the passion & helping there communities & support their families go home in peace. The trailer is a terrible example more like images what cops use to do more likely 25 to 30 years ago. Plus everyone now a days know to always comply what an officer says especially when you have nothing to hide or done. It’s easy not hard. In that trailer situation cops tell you to keep your hands on the hood because police officers are trained for different spilt situations an outcomes if necessary to save their own lives. No one ever reaches into there cars, pockets or moves their own hands away from the stirring wheel when pulled over. But hey I know it’s a movie.. I just wanted to give an opinion. No cop ever wakes up in the morning wanting to shoot somebody. it’s the situation. Understand Both sides before you try to become Judge & Jury.

The Hate U Give had been high up on the NYT bestseller list for over a year. Angie Thomas, the author of THUG, is truly and inspiration.
